trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory hybrid identity design considerations - define data protection strategy | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory hybrid identity design considerations - define data protection strategy | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: You’ll define the data protection strategy for your hybrid identity solution to meet the business requirements that you defined.
trans-unit.target: You’ll define the data protection strategy for your hybrid identity solution to meet the business requirements that you defined.

trans-unit.source: Define data protection strategy for your hybrid identity solution
trans-unit.target: Define data protection strategy for your hybrid identity solution

trans-unit.source: In this task, you’ll define the data protection strategy for your hybrid identity solution to meet the business requirements that you defined in:
trans-unit.target: In this task, you’ll define the data protection strategy for your hybrid identity solution to meet the business requirements that you defined in:

trans-unit.target: Determine data protection requirements

trans-unit.target: Determine access control requirements

trans-unit.source: Define data protection options
trans-unit.target: Define data protection options

trans-unit.source: As it was explained in [Determine directory synchronization requirements](active-directory-hybrid-identity-design-considerations-directory-sync-requirements.md), Microsoft Azure AD can synchronize with your Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) located on-premises.
trans-unit.target: As it was explained in [Determine directory synchronization requirements](active-directory-hybrid-identity-design-considerations-directory-sync-requirements.md), Microsoft Azure AD can synchronize with your Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) located on-premises.

trans-unit.source: This integration enables organizations to leverage Azure AD to verify user’s credentials when they are trying to access corporate resources.
trans-unit.target: This integration enables organizations to leverage Azure AD to verify user’s credentials when they are trying to access corporate resources.

trans-unit.source: This can be done for both scenarios: data at rest on-premises and in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: This can be done for both scenarios: data at rest on-premises and in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Access to data in Azure AD requires user authentication via a security token service (STS).
trans-unit.target: Access to data in Azure AD requires user authentication via a security token service (STS).

trans-unit.source: Once authenticated, the user principal name (UPN) is read from the authentication token and the replicated partition and container corresponding to the user’s domain is determined.
trans-unit.target: Once authenticated, the user principal name (UPN) is read from the authentication token and the replicated partition and container corresponding to the user’s domain is determined.

trans-unit.source: Information on the user’s existence, enabled state, and role is used by the authorization system to determine whether the requested access to the target tenant is authorized for this user in this session.
trans-unit.target: Information on the user’s existence, enabled state, and role is used by the authorization system to determine whether the requested access to the target tenant is authorized for this user in this session.

trans-unit.source: Certain authorized actions (specifically, create user, password reset) create an audit trail that can be used by a tenant administrator to manage compliance efforts or investigations.
trans-unit.target: Certain authorized actions (specifically, create user, password reset) create an audit trail that can be used by a tenant administrator to manage compliance efforts or investigations.

trans-unit.source: Moving data from your on-premises datacenter into Azure Storage over an Internet connection may not always be feasible due to data volume, bandwidth availability, or other considerations.
trans-unit.target: Moving data from your on-premises datacenter into Azure Storage over an Internet connection may not always be feasible due to data volume, bandwidth availability, or other considerations.

trans-unit.source: The [Azure Storage Import/Export Service](../storage/storage-import-export-service.md) provides a hardware-based option for placing/retrieving large volumes of data in blob storage.
trans-unit.target: The [Azure Storage Import/Export Service](../storage/storage-import-export-service.md) provides a hardware-based option for placing/retrieving large volumes of data in blob storage.

trans-unit.source: It allows you to send [BitLocker-encrypted](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn306081#BKMK_BL2012R2) hard disk drives directly to an Azure datacenter where cloud operators will upload the contents to your storage account, or they can download your Azure data to your drives to return to you.
trans-unit.target: It allows you to send [BitLocker-encrypted](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn306081#BKMK_BL2012R2) hard disk drives directly to an Azure datacenter where cloud operators will upload the contents to your storage account, or they can download your Azure data to your drives to return to you.

trans-unit.source: Only encrypted disks are accepted for this process (using a BitLocker key generated by the service itself during the job setup).
trans-unit.target: Only encrypted disks are accepted for this process (using a BitLocker key generated by the service itself during the job setup).

trans-unit.source: The BitLocker key is provided to Azure separately, thus providing out of band key sharing.
trans-unit.target: The BitLocker key is provided to Azure separately, thus providing out of band key sharing.

trans-unit.source: Since data in transit can take place in different scenarios, is also relevant to know that Microsoft Azure uses [virtual networking](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/virtual-network/) to isolate tenants’ traffic from one another, employing measures such as host- and guest-level firewalls, IP packet filtering, port blocking, and HTTPS endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Since data in transit can take place in different scenarios, is also relevant to know that Microsoft Azure uses [virtual networking](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/virtual-network/) to isolate tenants’ traffic from one another, employing measures such as host- and guest-level firewalls, IP packet filtering, port blocking, and HTTPS endpoints.

trans-unit.source: However, most of Azure’s internal communications, including infrastructure-to-infrastructure and infrastructure-to-customer (on-premises), are also encrypted.
trans-unit.target: However, most of Azure’s internal communications, including infrastructure-to-infrastructure and infrastructure-to-customer (on-premises), are also encrypted.

trans-unit.source: Another important scenario is the communications within Azure datacenters; Microsoft manages networks to assure that no VM can impersonate or eavesdrop on the IP address of another.
trans-unit.target: Another important scenario is the communications within Azure datacenters; Microsoft manages networks to assure that no VM can impersonate or eavesdrop on the IP address of another.

trans-unit.source: TLS/SSL is used when accessing Azure Storage or SQL Databases, or when connecting to Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: TLS/SSL is used when accessing Azure Storage or SQL Databases, or when connecting to Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the customer administrator is responsible for obtaining a TLS/SSL certificate and deploying it to their tenant infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the customer administrator is responsible for obtaining a TLS/SSL certificate and deploying it to their tenant infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Data traffic moving between Virtual Machines in the same deployment or between tenants in a single deployment via Microsoft Azure Virtual Network can be protected through encrypted communication protocols such as HTTPS, SSL/TLS, or others.
trans-unit.target: Data traffic moving between Virtual Machines in the same deployment or between tenants in a single deployment via Microsoft Azure Virtual Network can be protected through encrypted communication protocols such as HTTPS, SSL/TLS, or others.

trans-unit.source: Depending on how you answered the questions in [Determine data protection requirements](active-directory-hybrid-identity-design-considerations-dataprotection-requirements.md), you should be able to determine how you want to protect your data and how the hybrid identity solution will assist you on that.
trans-unit.target: Depending on how you answered the questions in [Determine data protection requirements](active-directory-hybrid-identity-design-considerations-dataprotection-requirements.md), you should be able to determine how you want to protect your data and how the hybrid identity solution will assist you on that.

trans-unit.source: The table shows the options supported by Azure that are available for each data protection scenario.
trans-unit.target: The table shows the options supported by Azure that are available for each data protection scenario.

trans-unit.target: Data protection options

trans-unit.target: At rest in the cloud

trans-unit.source: At rest on-premises
trans-unit.target: At rest on-premises

trans-unit.source: In transit
trans-unit.target: In transit

trans-unit.target: BitLocker Drive Encryption

trans-unit.target: X

trans-unit.target: X

trans-unit.target: SQL Server to encrypt databases

trans-unit.target: X

trans-unit.source: X
trans-unit.target: X

trans-unit.target: VM-to-VM Encryption

trans-unit.source: X
trans-unit.target: X

trans-unit.source: Read [Compliance by Feature](http://azure.microsoft.com/support/trust-center/services/) at [Microsoft Azure Trust Center](http://azure.microsoft.com/support/trust-center/) to know more about the certifications that each Azure service is compliant with.
trans-unit.target: Read [Compliance by Feature](http://azure.microsoft.com/support/trust-center/services/) at [Microsoft Azure Trust Center](http://azure.microsoft.com/support/trust-center/) to know more about the certifications that each Azure service is compliant with.

trans-unit.source: Since the options for data protection use a multilayer approach, comparison between those options are not applicable for this task.
trans-unit.target: Since the options for data protection use a multilayer approach, comparison between those options are not applicable for this task.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you are leveraging all options available for each state that the data will be.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you are leveraging all options available for each state that the data will be.

trans-unit.source: Define content management options
trans-unit.target: Define content management options

trans-unit.source: One advantage of using Azure AD to manage a hybrid identity infrastructure is that the process is fully transparent from the end user’s perspective.
trans-unit.target: One advantage of using Azure AD to manage a hybrid identity infrastructure is that the process is fully transparent from the end user’s perspective.

trans-unit.source: The user will try to access a shared resource, the resource requires authentication, the user will have to send an authentication request to Azure AD in order to obtain the token and access the resource.
trans-unit.target: The user will try to access a shared resource, the resource requires authentication, the user will have to send an authentication request to Azure AD in order to obtain the token and access the resource.

trans-unit.source: This entire process happens in background, without user interaction.
trans-unit.target: This entire process happens in background, without user interaction.

trans-unit.source: It is also possible to grant permission to a [group](active-directory-manage-groups.md#getting-started-with-access-management) of users in order to allow them to perform certain common actions.
trans-unit.target: It is also possible to grant permission to a [group](active-directory-manage-groups.md#getting-started-with-access-management) of users in order to allow them to perform certain common actions.

trans-unit.source: Organizations that are concern about data privacy usually require data classification for their solution.
trans-unit.target: Organizations that are concern about data privacy usually require data classification for their solution.

trans-unit.source: If their current on-premises infrastructure is already using data classification, it is possible to leverage Azure AD as the main repository for user’s identity.
trans-unit.target: If their current on-premises infrastructure is already using data classification, it is possible to leverage Azure AD as the main repository for user’s identity.

trans-unit.source: A common tool that it is used on-premises for data classification is called [Data Classification Toolkit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/Hh204743.aspx) for Windows Server 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: A common tool that it is used on-premises for data classification is called [Data Classification Toolkit](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/Hh204743.aspx) for Windows Server 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: This tool can help to identify, classify, and protect data on file servers in your private cloud.
trans-unit.target: This tool can help to identify, classify, and protect data on file servers in your private cloud.

trans-unit.source: It is also possible to leverage the [Automatic File Classification](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh831672.aspx) in Windows Server 2012 to accomplish this.
trans-unit.target: It is also possible to leverage the [Automatic File Classification](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh831672.aspx) in Windows Server 2012 to accomplish this.

trans-unit.source: If your organization doesn’t have data classification in place but needs to protect sensitive files without adding new Servers on-premises, they can use Microsoft [Azure Rights Management Service](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/JJ585026.aspx).
trans-unit.target: If your organization doesn’t have data classification in place but needs to protect sensitive files without adding new Servers on-premises, they can use Microsoft [Azure Rights Management Service](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/JJ585026.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Azure RMS uses encryption, identity, and authorization policies to help secure your files and email, and it works across multiple devices—phones, tablets, and PCs.
trans-unit.target: Azure RMS uses encryption, identity, and authorization policies to help secure your files and email, and it works across multiple devices—phones, tablets, and PCs.

trans-unit.source: Because Azure RMS is a cloud service, there’s no need to explicitly configure trusts with other organizations before you can share protected content with them.
trans-unit.target: Because Azure RMS is a cloud service, there’s no need to explicitly configure trusts with other organizations before you can share protected content with them.

trans-unit.source: If they already have an Office 365 or an Azure AD directory, collaboration across organizations is automatically supported.
trans-unit.target: If they already have an Office 365 or an Azure AD directory, collaboration across organizations is automatically supported.

trans-unit.source: You can also synchronize just the directory attributes that Azure RMS needs to support a common identity for your on-premises Active Directory accounts, by using Azure Active Directory Synchronization Services (AAD Sync) or Azure AD Connect.
trans-unit.target: You can also synchronize just the directory attributes that Azure RMS needs to support a common identity for your on-premises Active Directory accounts, by using Azure Active Directory Synchronization Services (AAD Sync) or Azure AD Connect.

trans-unit.source: A vital part of content management is to understand who is accessing which resource, therefore a rich logging capability is important for the identity management solution.
trans-unit.target: A vital part of content management is to understand who is accessing which resource, therefore a rich logging capability is important for the identity management solution.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD provides log over 30 days including:
trans-unit.target: Azure AD provides log over 30 days including:

trans-unit.source: Changes in role membership (ex: user added to Global Admin role)
trans-unit.target: Changes in role membership (ex: user added to Global Admin role)

trans-unit.source: Credential updates (ex: password changes)
trans-unit.target: Credential updates (ex: password changes)

trans-unit.source: Domain management (ex: verifying a custom domain, removing a domain)
trans-unit.target: Domain management (ex: verifying a custom domain, removing a domain)

trans-unit.source: Adding or removing applications
trans-unit.target: Adding or removing applications

trans-unit.source: User management (ex: adding, removing, updating a user)
trans-unit.target: User management (ex: adding, removing, updating a user)

trans-unit.source: Adding or removing licenses
trans-unit.target: Adding or removing licenses

trans-unit.source: Read [Microsoft Azure Security and Audit Log Management](http://download.microsoft.com/download/B/6/C/B6C0A98B-D34A-417C-826E-3EA28CDFC9DD/AzureSecurityandAuditLogManagement_11132014.pdf) to know more about logging capabilities in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Read [Microsoft Azure Security and Audit Log Management](http://download.microsoft.com/download/B/6/C/B6C0A98B-D34A-417C-826E-3EA28CDFC9DD/AzureSecurityandAuditLogManagement_11132014.pdf) to know more about logging capabilities in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Depending on how you answered the questions in [Determine content management requirements](active-directory-hybrid-identity-design-considerations-contentmgt-requirements.md), you should be able to determine how you want the content to be managed in your hybrid identity solution.
trans-unit.target: Depending on how you answered the questions in [Determine content management requirements](active-directory-hybrid-identity-design-considerations-contentmgt-requirements.md), you should be able to determine how you want the content to be managed in your hybrid identity solution.

trans-unit.source: While all options exposed in Table 6 are capable of integrating with Azure AD, it is important to define which is more appropriate for your business needs.
trans-unit.target: While all options exposed in Table 6 are capable of integrating with Azure AD, it is important to define which is more appropriate for your business needs.

trans-unit.source: Content management options
trans-unit.target: Content management options

trans-unit.source: Advantages
trans-unit.target: Advantages

trans-unit.source: Disadvantages
trans-unit.target: Disadvantages

trans-unit.source: Centralized on-premises (Active Directory Rights Management Server)
trans-unit.target: Centralized on-premises (Active Directory Rights Management Server)

trans-unit.source: Full control over the server infrastructure responsible for classifying the data
trans-unit.target: Full control over the server infrastructure responsible for classifying the data

trans-unit.source: Built-in capability in Windows Server, no need for extra license or subscription
trans-unit.target: Built-in capability in Windows Server, no need for extra license or subscription

trans-unit.source: Can be integrated with Azure AD in a hybrid scenario
trans-unit.target: Can be integrated with Azure AD in a hybrid scenario

trans-unit.source: Supports information rights management (IRM) capabilities in Microsoft Online services such as Exchange Online and SharePoint Online, as well as Office 365
trans-unit.target: Supports information rights management (IRM) capabilities in Microsoft Online services such as Exchange Online and SharePoint Online, as well as Office 365

trans-unit.source: Supports on-premises Microsoft server products, such as Exchange Server, SharePoint Server, and file servers that run Windows Server and File Classification Infrastructure (FCI).
trans-unit.target: Supports on-premises Microsoft server products, such as Exchange Server, SharePoint Server, and file servers that run Windows Server and File Classification Infrastructure (FCI).

trans-unit.source: Higher,maintenance (keep up with updates, configuration and potential upgrades),since IT owns the Server
trans-unit.target: Higher,maintenance (keep up with updates, configuration and potential upgrades),since IT owns the Server

trans-unit.source: Require a server infrastructure on-premises
trans-unit.target: Require a server infrastructure on-premises

trans-unit.source: Doesn’tleverage Azure capabilities natively
trans-unit.target: Doesn’tleverage Azure capabilities natively

trans-unit.source: Centralized in the cloud (Azure RMS)
trans-unit.target: Centralized in the cloud (Azure RMS)

trans-unit.source: Easier to manage compared to the on-premises solution
trans-unit.target: Easier to manage compared to the on-premises solution

trans-unit.source: Can be integrated with AD DS in a hybrid scenario
trans-unit.target: Can be integrated with AD DS in a hybrid scenario

trans-unit.source: Fully integrated with Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Fully integrated with Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Doesn’t require a server on-premises in order to deploy the service
trans-unit.target: Doesn’t require a server on-premises in order to deploy the service

trans-unit.source: Supports on-premises Microsoft server products such as Exchange Server, SharePoint,Server, and file servers that run Windows Server and File Classification,Infrastructure (FCI)
trans-unit.target: Supports on-premises Microsoft server products such as Exchange Server, SharePoint,Server, and file servers that run Windows Server and File Classification,Infrastructure (FCI)

trans-unit.source: IT,can have complete control over their tenant’s key with BYOK capability.
trans-unit.target: IT,can have complete control over their tenant’s key with BYOK capability.

trans-unit.source: Your organization must have a cloud subscription that supports RMS
trans-unit.target: Your organization must have a cloud subscription that supports RMS

trans-unit.source: Your organization must have an Azure AD directory to support user authentication for RMS
trans-unit.target: Your organization must have an Azure AD directory to support user authentication for RMS

trans-unit.source: Hybrid (Azure RMS integrated with,On-Premises Active Directory Rights Management Server)
trans-unit.target: Hybrid (Azure RMS integrated with,On-Premises Active Directory Rights Management Server)

trans-unit.source: This scenario accumulates the advantages of both, centralized on-premises and in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: This scenario accumulates the advantages of both, centralized on-premises and in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Your organization must have a cloud subscription that supports RMS
trans-unit.target: Your organization must have a cloud subscription that supports RMS

trans-unit.source: Your organization must have an Azure AD directory to support user authentication for RMS,
trans-unit.target: Your organization must have an Azure AD directory to support user authentication for RMS,

trans-unit.source: Requires a connection between Azure cloud service and on-premises infrastructure
trans-unit.target: Requires a connection between Azure cloud service and on-premises infrastructure

trans-unit.source: Define access control options
trans-unit.target: Define access control options

trans-unit.source: By leveraging the authentication, authorization and access control capabilities available in Azure AD you will be able to enable your company to use a central identity repository while allowing users and partners to use single sign-on (SSO) as shown in the figure below:
trans-unit.target: By leveraging the authentication, authorization and access control capabilities available in Azure AD you will be able to enable your company to use a central identity repository while allowing users and partners to use single sign-on (SSO) as shown in the figure below:

trans-unit.source: Centralized management and fully integration with other directories
trans-unit.target: Centralized management and fully integration with other directories

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory provides single sign-on to thousands of SaaS applications and on-premises web applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory provides single sign-on to thousands of SaaS applications and on-premises web applications.

trans-unit.source: Please read the [Azure Active Directory federation compatibility list: third-party identity providers that can be used to implement single sign-on](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj679342.aspx) article for more details about the SSO third-party that were tested by Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: Please read the [Azure Active Directory federation compatibility list: third-party identity providers that can be used to implement single sign-on](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj679342.aspx) article for more details about the SSO third-party that were tested by Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: This capability enables organization to implement a variety of B2B scenarios while keeping control of the identity and access management.
trans-unit.target: This capability enables organization to implement a variety of B2B scenarios while keeping control of the identity and access management.

trans-unit.source: However, during the B2B designing process is important to understand the authentication method that will be used by the partner and validate if this method is supported by Azure.
trans-unit.target: However, during the B2B designing process is important to understand the authentication method that will be used by the partner and validate if this method is supported by Azure.

trans-unit.source: Currently these are methods supported by Azure AD:
trans-unit.target: Currently these are methods supported by Azure AD:

trans-unit.source: Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML)
trans-unit.target: Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML)

trans-unit.source: OAuth
trans-unit.target: OAuth

trans-unit.source: Kerberos
trans-unit.target: Kerberos

trans-unit.source: Tokens
trans-unit.target: Tokens

trans-unit.source: Certificates
trans-unit.target: Certificates

trans-unit.source: Read [Azure Active Directory Authentication Protocols](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn151124.aspx) to know more details about each protocol and its capabilities in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Read [Azure Active Directory Authentication Protocols](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn151124.aspx) to know more details about each protocol and its capabilities in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure AD support, mobile business applications can use the same easy Mobile Services authentication experience to allow employees to sign into their mobile applications with their corporate Active Directory credentials.
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure AD support, mobile business applications can use the same easy Mobile Services authentication experience to allow employees to sign into their mobile applications with their corporate Active Directory credentials.

trans-unit.source: With this feature, Azure AD is supported as an identity provider in Mobile Services alongside with the other identity providers we already support (which include Microsoft Accounts, Facebook ID, Google ID, and Twitter ID).
trans-unit.target: With this feature, Azure AD is supported as an identity provider in Mobile Services alongside with the other identity providers we already support (which include Microsoft Accounts, Facebook ID, Google ID, and Twitter ID).

trans-unit.source: If the on-premises apps uses the user’s credential located at the company’s AD DS, the access from partners and users coming from the cloud should be transparent.
trans-unit.target: If the on-premises apps uses the user’s credential located at the company’s AD DS, the access from partners and users coming from the cloud should be transparent.

trans-unit.source: You can manage user’s conditional access control to (cloud-based) web applications, web API, Microsoft cloud services, 3rd party SaaS applications, and native (mobile) client applications, and have the benefits of security, auditing, reporting all in one place.
trans-unit.target: You can manage user’s conditional access control to (cloud-based) web applications, web API, Microsoft cloud services, 3rd party SaaS applications, and native (mobile) client applications, and have the benefits of security, auditing, reporting all in one place.

trans-unit.source: However, it is recommended to validate this in a non-production environment or with a limited amount of users.
trans-unit.target: However, it is recommended to validate this in a non-production environment or with a limited amount of users.

trans-unit.source: It is important to mention that Azure AD does not have Group Policy as AD DS has.
trans-unit.target: It is important to mention that Azure AD does not have Group Policy as AD DS has.

trans-unit.source: In order to enforce policy for devices you will need a mobile device management solution such as [Microsoft Intune](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj676587.aspx).
trans-unit.target: In order to enforce policy for devices you will need a mobile device management solution such as [Microsoft Intune](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/jj676587.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Once the user is authenticated using Azure AD, it is important to evaluate the level of access that the user will have it.
trans-unit.target: Once the user is authenticated using Azure AD, it is important to evaluate the level of access that the user will have it.

trans-unit.source: The level of access that the user will have over a resource can vary, while Azure AD can add an additional security layer by controlling access to some resources, you must also keep in mind that the resource itself can also have its own access control list separately, such as the access control for files located in a File Server.
trans-unit.target: The level of access that the user will have over a resource can vary, while Azure AD can add an additional security layer by controlling access to some resources, you must also keep in mind that the resource itself can also have its own access control list separately, such as the access control for files located in a File Server.

trans-unit.source: The figure below summarizes the levels of access control that you can have in a hybrid scenario:
trans-unit.target: The figure below summarizes the levels of access control that you can have in a hybrid scenario:

trans-unit.source: Each interaction in the diagram showed in Figure X represents one access control scenario that can be covered by Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Each interaction in the diagram showed in Figure X represents one access control scenario that can be covered by Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Below you have a description of each scenario:
trans-unit.target: Below you have a description of each scenario:

trans-unit.source: Conditional Access to applications that are hosted on-premises: You can use registered devices with access policies for applications that are configured to use AD FS with Windows Server 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: Conditional Access to applications that are hosted on-premises: You can use registered devices with access policies for applications that are configured to use AD FS with Windows Server 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: For more information about setting up conditional access for on-premises, see [Setting up On-premises Conditional Access using Azure Active Directory Device Registration](active-directory-conditional-access-on-premises-setup.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about setting up conditional access for on-premises, see [Setting up On-premises Conditional Access using Azure Active Directory Device Registration](active-directory-conditional-access-on-premises-setup.md).

trans-unit.source: Access Control to Azure Management Portal: Azure also has the capability to control access to the Management Portal by using RBAC (Role Based Access Control).
trans-unit.target: Access Control to Azure Management Portal: Azure also has the capability to control access to the Management Portal by using RBAC (Role Based Access Control).

trans-unit.source: This method enables the company to restrict the amount of operations that an individual can do once he has access to Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This method enables the company to restrict the amount of operations that an individual can do once he has access to Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: By using RBAC to control access to the portal, IT Admins ca delegate access by using the following access management approaches:
trans-unit.target: By using RBAC to control access to the portal, IT Admins ca delegate access by using the following access management approaches:

trans-unit.source: Group-based role assignment: You can assign access to Azure AD groups that can be synced from your local Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Group-based role assignment: You can assign access to Azure AD groups that can be synced from your local Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to leverage the existing investments that your organization has made in tooling and processes for managing groups.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to leverage the existing investments that your organization has made in tooling and processes for managing groups.

trans-unit.source: You can also use the delegated group management feature of Azure AD Premium.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the delegated group management feature of Azure AD Premium.

trans-unit.source: Leverage built in roles in Azure: You can use three roles — Owner, Contributor, and Reader, to ensure that users and groups have permission to do only the tasks they need to do their jobs.
trans-unit.target: Leverage built in roles in Azure: You can use three roles — Owner, Contributor, and Reader, to ensure that users and groups have permission to do only the tasks they need to do their jobs.

trans-unit.source: Granular access to resources: You can assign roles to users and groups for a particular subscription, resource group, or an individual Azure resource such as a website or database.
trans-unit.target: Granular access to resources: You can assign roles to users and groups for a particular subscription, resource group, or an individual Azure resource such as a website or database.

trans-unit.source: In this way, you can ensure that users have access to all the resources they need and no access to resources that they do not need to manage.
trans-unit.target: In this way, you can ensure that users have access to all the resources they need and no access to resources that they do not need to manage.

trans-unit.source: Read [Role-based access control in Azure Preview portal](http://azure.microsoft.com/updates/role-based-access-control-in-azure-preview-portal/) to know more details about this capability.
trans-unit.target: Read [Role-based access control in Azure Preview portal](http://azure.microsoft.com/updates/role-based-access-control-in-azure-preview-portal/) to know more details about this capability.

trans-unit.source: For developers that are building applications and want to customize the access control for them, it is also possible to use Azure AD Application Roles for authorization.
trans-unit.target: For developers that are building applications and want to customize the access control for them, it is also possible to use Azure AD Application Roles for authorization.

trans-unit.source: Review this [WebApp-RoleClaims-DotNet example](https://github.com/AzureADSamples/WebApp-RoleClaims-DotNet) on how to build your app to use this capability.
trans-unit.target: Review this [WebApp-RoleClaims-DotNet example](https://github.com/AzureADSamples/WebApp-RoleClaims-DotNet) on how to build your app to use this capability.

trans-unit.source: Conditional Access for Office 365 applications with Microsoft Intune: IT admins can provision conditional access device policies to secure corporate resources, while at the same time allowing information workers on compliant devices to access the services.
trans-unit.target: Conditional Access for Office 365 applications with Microsoft Intune: IT admins can provision conditional access device policies to secure corporate resources, while at the same time allowing information workers on compliant devices to access the services.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Conditional Access Device Policies for Office 365 services](active-directory-conditional-access-device-policies.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Conditional Access Device Policies for Office 365 services](active-directory-conditional-access-device-policies.md).

trans-unit.source: Conditional Access for Saas apps: [This feature](http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/25/azure-ad-conditional-access-preview-update-more-apps-and-blocking-access-for-users-not-at-work.aspx) allows you to configure per-application multi-factor authentication access rules and the ability to block access for users not on a trusted network.
trans-unit.target: Conditional Access for Saas apps: [This feature](http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/25/azure-ad-conditional-access-preview-update-more-apps-and-blocking-access-for-users-not-at-work.aspx) allows you to configure per-application multi-factor authentication access rules and the ability to block access for users not on a trusted network.

trans-unit.source: You can apply the multi-factor authentication rules to all users that are assigned to the application, or only for users within specified security groups.
trans-unit.target: You can apply the multi-factor authentication rules to all users that are assigned to the application, or only for users within specified security groups.

trans-unit.source: Users may be excluded from the multi-factor authentication requirement if they are accessing the application from an IP address that in inside the organization’s network.
trans-unit.target: Users may be excluded from the multi-factor authentication requirement if they are accessing the application from an IP address that in inside the organization’s network.

trans-unit.source: Since the options for access control use a multilayer approach, comparison between those options are not applicable for this task.
trans-unit.target: Since the options for access control use a multilayer approach, comparison between those options are not applicable for this task.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you are leveraging all options available for each scenario that requires you to control access to your resources.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you are leveraging all options available for each scenario that requires you to control access to your resources.

trans-unit.source: Define incident response options
trans-unit.target: Define incident response options

trans-unit.source: Azure AD can assist IT to identity potential security risks in the environment by monitoring user’s activity, IT can leverage Azure AD Access and Usage reports capability to gain visibility into the integrity and security of your organization’s directory.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD can assist IT to identity potential security risks in the environment by monitoring user’s activity, IT can leverage Azure AD Access and Usage reports capability to gain visibility into the integrity and security of your organization’s directory.

trans-unit.source: With this information, an IT admin can better determine where possible security risks may lie so that they can adequately plan to mitigate those risks.
trans-unit.target: With this information, an IT admin can better determine where possible security risks may lie so that they can adequately plan to mitigate those risks.

trans-unit.source: [Azure AD Premium subscription](articles/active-directory-get-started-premium.md) has a set of security reports that can enable IT to obtain this information.
trans-unit.target: [Azure AD Premium subscription](articles/active-directory-get-started-premium.md) has a set of security reports that can enable IT to obtain this information.

trans-unit.source: [Azure AD reports](active-directory-view-access-usage-reports.md) are categorized as shown below:
trans-unit.target: [Azure AD reports](active-directory-view-access-usage-reports.md) are categorized as shown below:

trans-unit.source: **Anomaly reports**: Contain sign in events that we found to be anomalous.
trans-unit.target: **Anomaly reports**: Contain sign in events that we found to be anomalous.

trans-unit.source: Our goal is to make you aware of such activity and enable you to be able to make a determination about whether an event is suspicious.
trans-unit.target: Our goal is to make you aware of such activity and enable you to be able to make a determination about whether an event is suspicious.

trans-unit.source: **Integrated Application report**: Provides insights into how cloud applications are being used in your organization.
trans-unit.target: **Integrated Application report**: Provides insights into how cloud applications are being used in your organization.

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory offers integration with thousands of cloud applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory offers integration with thousands of cloud applications.

trans-unit.source: **Error reports**: Indicate errors that may occur when provisioning accounts to external applications.
trans-unit.target: **Error reports**: Indicate errors that may occur when provisioning accounts to external applications.

trans-unit.source: **User-specific reports**: Display device/sign in activity data for a specific user.
trans-unit.target: **User-specific reports**: Display device/sign in activity data for a specific user.

trans-unit.source: **Activity logs**: Contain a record of all audited events within the last 24 hours, last 7 days, or last 30 days, as well as group activity changes, and password reset and registration activity.
trans-unit.target: **Activity logs**: Contain a record of all audited events within the last 24 hours, last 7 days, or last 30 days, as well as group activity changes, and password reset and registration activity.

trans-unit.source: Another report that can also help the Incident Response team working on a case is the [user with leaked credentials](http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/15/azure-active-directory-premium-reporting-now-detects-leaked-credentials.aspx) report.
trans-unit.target: Another report that can also help the Incident Response team working on a case is the [user with leaked credentials](http://blogs.technet.com/b/ad/archive/2015/06/15/azure-active-directory-premium-reporting-now-detects-leaked-credentials.aspx) report.

trans-unit.source: This report surfaces any matches between these leaked credentials list and your tenant.
trans-unit.target: This report surfaces any matches between these leaked credentials list and your tenant.

trans-unit.source: Other important built in reports in Azure AD that can be used during an incident response investigation and are:
trans-unit.target: Other important built in reports in Azure AD that can be used during an incident response investigation and are:

trans-unit.source: **Password reset activity**: provide the admin with insights into how actively password reset is being used in the organization.
trans-unit.target: **Password reset activity**: provide the admin with insights into how actively password reset is being used in the organization.

trans-unit.source: **Password reset registration activity**: provides insights into which users have registered their methods for password reset, and which methods they have selected.
trans-unit.target: **Password reset registration activity**: provides insights into which users have registered their methods for password reset, and which methods they have selected.

trans-unit.source: **Group activity**: provides a history of changes to the group (ex: users added or removed) that were initiated in the Access Panel.
trans-unit.target: **Group activity**: provides a history of changes to the group (ex: users added or removed) that were initiated in the Access Panel.

trans-unit.source: In addition to the core reporting capability available in Azure AD Premium that can be leveraged during an Incident Response investigation process, IT can also leverage Audit Report to obtain information such as:
trans-unit.target: In addition to the core reporting capability available in Azure AD Premium that can be leveraged during an Incident Response investigation process, IT can also leverage Audit Report to obtain information such as:

trans-unit.source: Changes in role membership (ex: user added to Global Admin role)
trans-unit.target: Changes in role membership (ex: user added to Global Admin role)

trans-unit.source: Credential updates (ex: password changes)
trans-unit.target: Credential updates (ex: password changes)

trans-unit.source: Domain management (ex: verifying a custom domain, removing a domain)
trans-unit.target: Domain management (ex: verifying a custom domain, removing a domain)

trans-unit.source: Adding or removing applications
trans-unit.target: Adding or removing applications

trans-unit.source: User management (ex: adding, removing, updating a user)
trans-unit.target: User management (ex: adding, removing, updating a user)

trans-unit.source: Adding or removing licenses
trans-unit.target: Adding or removing licenses

trans-unit.source: Since the options for incident response use a multilayer approach, comparison between those options are not applicable for this task.
trans-unit.target: Since the options for incident response use a multilayer approach, comparison between those options are not applicable for this task.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you are leveraging all options available for each scenario that requires you to use Azure AD reporting capability as part of your company’s incident response process.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you are leveraging all options available for each scenario that requires you to use Azure AD reporting capability as part of your company’s incident response process.
